feedback.Physical object: Excluded — An algorithm is a formal procedure, not a tangible object.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — It is an entirely human-designed construct.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — Most are based on mathematical principles, not biological models.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Algorithms are abstract and exist independently of a fixed instantiation.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — The structure is logical, not physical.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Not directly observable outside of representation.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It is abstract and not made of matter.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Not applicable to a symbolic system.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Created with the explicit goal of securing data.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Included — Produces encrypted or hashed output.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Included — Executes logical transformations on input data.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Included — The algorithm's state changes in a predictable way in response to input and key, and it fundamentally transforms data (state).
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Interaction is mediated via interfaces or code; not intrinsic to the algorithm.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — A foundational component of secure systems and protocols.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Included — Once implemented, performs its function without human intervention.
feedback.System-critical: Included — In secure systems, failure of the algorithm breaks trust or functionality.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Uses formal symbolic rules to define transformations.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Enables secure communication by design.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Defined entirely by logical structure and deterministic operations.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Many algorithms are composed of layered steps (e.g., rounds, key expansion).
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Guides how systems and users structure secure data exchange.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Included — Algorithms often invoke themselves recursively or are designed using meta-principles.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Not inherently time-based, though execution occurs in time.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Behavior depends on key length, mode of operation, input format, etc.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Developed within academic, military, or corporate communities.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Standardized by institutions (e.g., NIST, IETF).
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Does not define personal or group identity.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Subject to export restrictions, compliance standards, and cryptographic regulations.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Foundational part of education in computer science and cybersecurity.
feedback.Visible: Included — Often published in papers, RFCs, code libraries, and documentation.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Implementation behavior depends on context of use.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Major algorithms are widely disseminated and scrutinized.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the Encryption Algorithm as a symbolic, logical, and socially governed construct with real functional significance. It is not a physical object but operates within highly structured technical and cultural frameworks. It is distinct from software *implementations* which would include more physical and functional traits.
